Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Understanding a landmark social insect radiation: comparative analysis, phylogenomics, and morphology of dorylomorph ants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Army ants, some of the most striking organisms, are found in warm temperate and tropical regions of the world. They are the most important invertebrate predators of the tropics, making them key species in rainforest ecosystems. This research will reconstruct the evolutionary history of army ants and their close relatives. The family tree of these ants, their geographic origins and the timeline of the evolution of traits that account for their ecological dominance will be investigated. An evolutionary tree will be constructed from the ants DNA using latest advances in molecular biology and bioinformatics. This tree will then serve as a framework for testing hypotheses on the evolution of army ant characteristics. This study will also provide a new framework for identification of army ants and closely related species.


This project will not only bring insights into the history of an ecologically important group of insects but also help to understand how the latest advances in molecular biology, statistics and computer science can improve our knowledge of evolutionary processes. New resources allowing easier and more accurate identification of these ants will aid other biologists and conservation specialists in decision making and planning further research on the group. A class on techniques in computational biology will be taught, promoting skills in efficient analysis of the ever-increasing volume of biological data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research that was aimed at understanding biological diversity and evolution of the natural world around us. This particular project focused on a group of ants called the Dorylinae, which includes the charismatic army ants and closely related species. The army ants are important predators of other insects and are known to be very important in the functioning of tropical ecosystems. Certain species are also important for nature conservation, as they can serve as sensitive indicators of whether a habitat was fragmented too much to support the biodiversity of the original habitat. Despite their ubiquity and importance, however, we know relatively little about when and where the army ant species originated or even how many species exist and how diverse they are.

In order to understand the evolution of this important group of insects we leveraged the latest developments in DNA (genetic material) sequencing and computing technologies. This NSF award allowed us to decipher significant portions of the ants’ genomes (all the genetic material, or blueprint for making an organism) and compare them across species to see what their evolutionary relationships, or family tree, look like. Because the amount of the genetic material involved is huge, manipulating this information was not trivial. Before we could get the DNA from the ants, however, we had to obtain the necessary material and be able to identify each species. This was only possible because of natural history collections that hold carefully curated material of all the species we so far know exist on Earth. Visiting several large museums was necessary to carry out this work.

There are many outcomes of this project that are significant or interesting from a scientific point of view, but several deserve highlighting because of their more general impact. First, a new resource for identification of all the major groups of the Dorylinae ants was created and published accessible free of charge. This will allow other researchers identify these ants more easily, without the need to visit numerous collections or consult experts. This is important, for example, to conservation biologists, who need to know what species they are dealing with in order to assess how vulnerable a habitat is. Second, by comparing the DNA from different species we were able to show that army ants evolved independently in the Old World and the Americas. Because army ants on all continents share a number of extraordinary traits, this result was surprising. It will hopefully stimulate other researchers to look at this fascinating group more closely and give insight into a more general question of how common independent concerted evolution of complex sets of characters is. Third, this research involved handling of ‘Big-Data’, which is an increasingly important factor in many scientific disciplines but also impacts the way we live through tracking of, for example, transactions or search terms of billions of internet users. An important outcome of this research included developing software that gives other biologists the tools needed to efficiently handle large amounts of genetic data from many species. Because computer programming is a skill that is becoming increasingly important in science, this award supported a class for biologists aimed toward teaching basic computer literacy. The class was taken by a number of graduate students and professors working in biology departments and even a medical school. It thus gave other researchers new tools to conduct their work more efficiently.

To summarize, this award supported a research project that increased our understanding of the natural world by uncovering previously unknown details about biological diversity and its evolution. It will stimulate other research because of new tools that can be used by anyone interested in comparing DNA across many species, and it promoted the much sought after skills of computer literacy by teaching a class geared towards other biologists. This research underscores the importance of old-fashioned natural history museum collections and bridges the gap between old and new approaches in biology by taking the advantage of and teaching skills that have only recently entered biology curriculums, such as scientific programming.
